# Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models

Wei Deng
Weijian Luo
Yixin Tan
Marin Biloš
Yu Chen
Yuriy Nevmyvaka
Ricky T. Q. Chen

###### Abstract

Schrödinger bridge (SB) has emerged as the go-to method for optimizing transportation plans in diffusion models. However, SB requires estimating the intractable forward score functions, inevitably resulting in the _costly_ implicit training loss based on simulated trajectories. To improve the scalability while preserving efficient transportation plans, we leverage variational inference to linearize the forward score functions (variational scores) of SB and restore _simulation-free_ properties in training backward scores. We propose the variational Schrödinger diffusion model (VSDM), where the forward process is a multivariate diffusion and the variational scores are adaptively optimized for efficient transport. Theoretically, we use stochastic approximation to prove the convergence of the variational scores and show the convergence of the adaptively generated samples based on the optimal variational scores. Empirically, we test the algorithm in simulated examples and observe that VSDM is efficient in generations of _anisotropic_ shapes and yields _straighter_ sample trajectories compared to the single-variate diffusion.
We also verify the scalability of the algorithm in real-world data and achieve competitive unconditional generation performance in CIFAR10 and conditional generation in time series modeling. Notably, VSDM no longer depends on warm-up initializations and has become tuning-friendly in training large-scale experiments.

Machine Learning, ICML

## 1 Introduction

Diffusion models have showcased remarkable proficiency across diverse domains, spanning large-scale generations of image, video, and audio, conditional text-to-image tasks, and adversarial defenses (Dhariwal & Nichol, [2022](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib20 ""); Ho et al., [2022](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib26 ""); Kong et al., [2021](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib35 ""); Ramesh et al., [2022](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib59 ""); Zhang et al., [2024](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib82 "")). The key to their scalability lies in the closed-form updates of the forward process, highlighting both statistical efficiency (Koehler et al., [2023](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib34 "")) and diminished dependence on dimensionality (Vono et al., [2022](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib80 "")). Nevertheless, diffusion models lack a distinct guarantee of optimal transport (OT) properties (Lavenant & Santambrogio, [2022](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib37 "")) and often necessitate costly evaluations to generate higher-fidelity content (Ho et al., [2020](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib25 ""); Salimans & Ho, [2022](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib63 ""); Lu et al., [2022](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib45 ""); Xue et al., [2023](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib81 ""); Luo, [2023](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib46 "")).

Alternatively, the Schrödinger bridge (SB) problem (Léonard, [2014](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib39 ""); Chen & Georgiou, [2016](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib14 ""); Pavon et al., [2021](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib54 ""); Caluya & Halder, [2022](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib8 ""); De Bortoli et al., [2021](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib18 "")), initially rooted in quantum mechanics (Léonard, [2014](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib39 "")), proposes optimizing a stochastic control objective through the use of forward-backward stochastic differential equations (FB-SDEs) (Chen et al., [2022b](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib12 "")). The alternating solver gives rise to the iterative proportional fitting (IPF) algorithm (Kullback, [1968](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib36 ""); Ruschendorf, [1995](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib62 "")) in dynamic optimal transport (Villani, [2003](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib79 ""); Peyré & Cuturi, [2019](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib56 "")). Notably, the intractable forward score function plays a crucial role in providing theoretical guarantees in optimal transport (Chen et al., [2023c](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib16 ""); Deng et al., [2024](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib19 "")). However, it simultaneously sacrifices the simulation-free property and largely relies on warm-up checkpoints for conducting large-scale experiments (De Bortoli et al., [2021](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib18 ""); Chen et al., [2022b](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib12 "")). A natural follow-up question arises:

Can we train diffusion models with efficient transport?

To this end, we introduce the variational Schrödinger diffusion model (VSDM). Employing variational inference (Blei et al., [2017](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib6 "")), we perform a locally linear approximation of the forward score function, and denote it by the variational score. The resulting linear _forward_ stochastic differential equations (SDEs) naturally provide a _closed-form update, significantly enhancing scalability_. Compared to the single-variate score-based generative model (SGM), VSDM is a multivariate diffusion (Singhal et al., [2023](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib67 "")). Moreover, hyperparameters are adaptively optimized for _more efficient transportation plans_ within the Schrödinger bridge framework (Chen et al., [2022b](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib12 "")).

Theoretically, we leverage stochastic approximation (Robbins & Monro, [1951](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib61 "")) to demonstrate the convergence of the variational score to the optimal local estimators. Although the global transport optimality is compromised, the notable _simulation-free_ speed-ups in training the backward score render the algorithm particularly attractive for training various generation tasks from scratch. Additionally, the efficiency of simulation-based training for the linearized variational score significantly improves owing to computational advancements in convex optimization. We validate the strength of VSDM through simulations, achieving compelling performance on standard image generation tasks. Our contributions unfold in four key aspects:

- •


We introduce the variational Schrödinger diffusion model (VSDM), a multivariate diffusion with _optimal variational scores_ guided by optimal transport. Additionally, the training of backward scores is _simulation-free_ and becomes much more scalable.

- •


We study the convergence of the variational score using stochastic approximation (SA) theory, which can be further generalized to a class of state space diffusion models for future developments.

- •


VSDM is effective in generating data of _anisotropic_ shapes and motivates _straighter_ transportation paths via the optimized transport.

- •


VSDM achieves competitive unconditional generation on CIFAR10 and conditional generation in time series modeling without reliance on warm-up initializations.


## 2 Related Works

##### Flow Matching and Beyond

Lipman et al. ( [2023](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib41 "")) utilized the McCann displacement interpolation (McCann, [1997](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib51 "")) to train simulation-free CNFs to encourage straight trajectories. Consequently, Pooladian et al. ( [2023](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib58 "")); Tong et al. ( [2023](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib73 "")) proposed straightening by using minibatch optimal transport solutions. Similar ideas were achieved by Liu ( [2022](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib43 "")); Liu et al. ( [2023](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib44 "")) to iteratively rectify the interpolation path. Albergo & Vanden-Eijnden ( [2023](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib1 "")); Albergo et al. ( [2023](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib2 "")) developed the stochastic interpolant approach to unify both flow and diffusion models. However, _“straighter” transport_ maps may not imply _optimal_ transportation plans in general and the couplings are still not effectively optimized.

##### Dynamic Optimal Transport

Finlay et al. ( [2020](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib22 "")); Onken et al. ( [2021](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib53 "")) introduced additional regularization through optimal transport to enforce straighter trajectories in CNFs and reduce the computational cost. De Bortoli et al. ( [2021](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib18 "")); Chen et al. ( [2022b](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib12 "")); Vargas et al. ( [2021](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib77 "")) studied the dynamic Schrödinger bridge with guarantees in entropic optimal transport (EOT) (Chen et al., [2023c](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib16 "")); Shi et al. ( [2023](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib66 "")); Peluchetti ( [2023](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib55 "")); Chen et al. ( [2023b](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib13 "")) generalized bridge matching and flow matching based EOT and obtained smoother trajectories, however, _scalability_ remains a significant concern for Schrödinger-based diffusions.

## 3 Preliminaries

### 3.1 Diffusion Models

The score-based generative models (SGMs) (Ho et al., [2020](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib25 ""); Song et al., [2021b](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib71 "")) first employ a forward process ( [1a](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#S3.E1.1 "Equation 1a ‣ Equation 1 ‣ 3.1 Diffusion Models ‣ 3 Preliminaries ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models")) to map data to an approximate Gaussian and subsequently reverse the process in Eq.( [1b](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#S3.E1.2 "Equation 1b ‣ Equation 1 ‣ 3.1 Diffusion Models ‣ 3 Preliminaries ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models")) to recover the data distribution.

## 4 Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models

SB outperforms SGMs in the theoretical potential of optimal transport and an intractable score function ∇log⁡ψ→t​(𝐱t)∇subscript→𝜓𝑡subscript𝐱𝑡\\nabla\\log\\overrightarrow{\\psi}\_{t}({\\bf x}\_{t}) is exploited in the forward SDE for more efficient transportation plans. However, there is no free lunch in achieving such efficiency, and it comes with three notable downsides:

- •


Solving ∇log⁡ψ→t∇subscript→𝜓𝑡\\nabla\\log\\overrightarrow{\\psi}\_{t} in Eq.( [5a](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#S3.E5.1 "Equation 5a ‣ Equation 5 ‣ 3.2 Schrödinger Bridge ‣ 3 Preliminaries ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models")) for optimal transport is prohibitively costly and may not be necessary (Marzouk et al., [2016](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib50 ""); Liu et al., [2023](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib44 "")).

- •


The nonlinear diffusion no longer yields closed-form expression of 𝐱→tsubscript→𝐱𝑡\\overrightarrow{{\\bf x}}\_{t} given 𝐱→0subscript→𝐱0\\overrightarrow{{\\bf x}}\_{0}(Chen et al., [2022b](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib12 "")).

- •


The ISM loss is inevitable and the estimator suffers from a large variance issue (Hutchinson, [1989](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib28 "")).


### 4.1 Variational Inference via Linear Approximation

FB-SDEs naturally connect to the alternating-projection solver based on the IPF (a.k.a. Sinkhorn) algorithm, boiling down the full bridge ( [3](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#S3.E3 "Equation 3 ‣ 3.2 Schrödinger Bridge ‣ 3 Preliminaries ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models")) to a half-bridge solver (Pavon et al., [2021](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib54 ""); De Bortoli et al., [2021](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib18 ""); Vargas et al., [2021](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib77 "")). ### 4.3 Adaptive Diffusion via Stochastic Approximation

Our major goal is to generate high-fidelity data with efficient transportation plans based on the optimal 𝐀t⋆superscriptsubscript𝐀𝑡⋆{\\mathrm{\\mathbf{A}}}\_{t}^{\\star} in the forward process ( [11](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#S4.E11 "Equation 11 ‣ 4.2 Closed-form Expression of Backward Score ‣ 4 Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models")). However, the optimal 𝐀t⋆superscriptsubscript𝐀𝑡⋆{\\mathrm{\\mathbf{A}}}\_{t}^{\\star} is not known _a priori_. To tackle this issue, we leverage stochastic approximation (SA) (Robbins & Monro, [1951](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib61 ""); Benveniste et al., [1990](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib5 "")) to adaptively optimize the variational score 𝐀t(k)superscriptsubscript𝐀𝑡𝑘{\\mathrm{\\mathbf{A}}}\_{t}^{(k)} through optimal transport and simulate the backward trajectories.

- (1)

##### Trajectory Averaging

The stochastic approximation algorithm is a standard framework to study adaptive sampling algorithms (Liang et al., [2007](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib40 "")). Moreover, the formulation suggests to stabilize the trajectories (Polyak & Juditsky, [1992](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib57 "")) with averaged parameters 𝐀¯n​h(k)superscriptsubscript¯𝐀𝑛ℎ𝑘\\overline{{\\mathrm{\\mathbf{A}}}}\_{nh}^{(k)} as follows

|     |     |     |
| --- | --- | --- |
|  | 𝐀¯n​h(k)=∑i=1k𝐀n​h(i)=(1−1k)​𝐀¯n​h(k−1)+1k​𝐀n​h(k),superscriptsubscript¯𝐀𝑛ℎ𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐀𝑛ℎ𝑖11𝑘superscriptsubscript¯𝐀𝑛ℎ𝑘11𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐀𝑛ℎ𝑘\\overline{{\\mathrm{\\mathbf{A}}}}\_{nh}^{(k)}=\\sum\_{i=1}^{k}{\\mathrm{\\mathbf{A}}}\_{nh}^{(i)}=\\bigg{(}1-\\frac{1}{k}\\bigg{)}\\overline{{\\mathrm{\\mathbf{A}}}}\_{nh}^{(k-1)}+\\frac{1}{k}{\\mathrm{\\mathbf{A}}}\_{nh}^{(k)}, |  |

where 𝐀¯n​h(k)superscriptsubscript¯𝐀𝑛ℎ𝑘\\overline{{\\mathrm{\\mathbf{A}}}}\_{nh}^{(k)} is known to be an asymptotically efficient (optimal) estimator (Polyak & Juditsky, [1992](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib57 "")) in the local state space 𝒜𝒜\\mathcal{A} by assumption [A1](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#Thmassump1 "Assumption A1 (Regularity). ‣ Appendix B Stochastic Approximation ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models").

##### Exponential Moving Average (EMA)

Despite guarantees in convex scenarios, the parameter space differs tremendously in different surfaces in non-convex state space 𝒜𝒜\\mathcal{A}. Empirically, if we want to exploit information from multiple modes, a standard extension is to employ the EMA technique (Trivedi & Kondor, [2017](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib74 "")):

|     |     |     |
| --- | --- | --- |
|  | 𝐀¯n​h(k)=(1−η)​𝐀¯n​h(k−1)+η​𝐀n​h(k),where ​η∈(0,1).formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript¯𝐀𝑛ℎ𝑘1𝜂superscriptsubscript¯𝐀𝑛ℎ𝑘1𝜂superscriptsubscript𝐀𝑛ℎ𝑘where 𝜂01\\overline{{\\mathrm{\\mathbf{A}}}}\_{nh}^{(k)}=(1-\\eta)\\overline{{\\mathrm{\\mathbf{A}}}}\_{nh}^{(k-1)}+\\eta{\\mathrm{\\mathbf{A}}}\_{nh}^{(k)},\\text{where }\\eta\\in(0,1). |  |

The EMA techniques are widely used empirically in diffusion models and Schrödinger bridge (Song & Ermon, [2020](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib68 ""); De Bortoli et al., [2021](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib18 ""); Chen et al., [2022b](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib12 "")) to avoid oscillating trajectories. Now we are ready to present our methodology in Algorithm [1](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#alg1 "Algorithm 1 ‣ 4.2.2 Probability Flow ODE ‣ 4.2 Closed-form Expression of Backward Score ‣ 4 Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models").

##### Computational Cost

Regarding the wall-clock computational time: i) training (linear) variational scores, albeit in a _simulation-based manner_, becomes significantly faster than estimating nonlinear forward scores in Schrödinger bridge; ii) the variational parametrization greatly reduced the number of model parameters, which yields a much-reduced variance in the Hutchinson’s estimator (Hutchinson, [1989](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib28 "")); iii) since we don’t need to update 𝐀tsubscript𝐀𝑡{\\mathrm{\\mathbf{A}}}\_{t} as often as the backward score model, we can further amortize the training of 𝐀tsubscript𝐀𝑡{\\mathrm{\\mathbf{A}}}\_{t}. In the simulation example in Figure. [9](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#A4.F9 "Figure 9 ‣ Convergence Study ‣ D.2.2 Convergence and Computational Time ‣ D.2 Synthetic Data ‣ Appendix D Experimental Details ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models")(b), VSDM is only 10% slower than the SGM with the same training complexity of backward scores while still maintaining efficient convergence of variational scores.

We also present the variational gap of the (sub)-optimal transport and show our transport is more efficient than diffusion models with Gaussian marginals.

Next, we outline informal assumptions and sketch our main results, reserving formal ones for readers interested in the details in the appendix. We also formulate the optimization of the variational score 𝐀tsubscript𝐀𝑡{\\mathrm{\\mathbf{A}}}\_{t} using stochastic approximation in Algorithm [2](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#alg2 "Algorithm 2 ‣ Appendix B Stochastic Approximation ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models") in the supplementary material.

𝐀t⋆∈𝚯⊂𝒜superscriptsubscript𝐀𝑡⋆𝚯𝒜{\\mathrm{\\mathbf{A}}}\_{t}^{\\star}\\in{\\mathrm{\\mathbf{\\Theta}}}\\subset\\mathcal{A} and 𝐋→tsubscript→𝐋𝑡\\overrightarrow{{\\mathrm{\\mathbf{L}}}}\_{t} is strongly convex in 𝚯𝚯{\\mathrm{\\mathbf{\\Theta}}}._

##### Connections to Gaussian Schrödinger bridge (GSB)

When data follows a Gaussian distribution, VSDM approximates the closed-form OT solution of Schrödinger bridge (Janati et al., [2020](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib30 ""); Bunne et al., [2023](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib7 "")). We refer readers to Theorem 3 (Bunne et al., [2023](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib7 "")) for the detailed transportation plans. Compared to the vanilla 𝐀t≡𝟎subscript𝐀𝑡0{\\mathrm{\\mathbf{A}}}\_{t}\\equiv\\bm{0}, we can significantly reduce the variational gap with KL​(L∥L⋆)KLconditionalLsuperscriptL⋆\\mathrm{KL}({\\mathrm{L}}\\\|{\\mathrm{L}}^{\\star}) using proper parametrization and sufficient training.

We briefly compare VSDM to SGM and SB in the following:

## 7 Empirical Studies

### 7.1 Comparison to Gaussian Schrodinger Bridge

VSDM is approximating GSB (Bunne et al., [2023](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib7 "")) when both marginals are Gaussian distributions. To evaluate the solutions, we run our VSDM with a fixed βt≡4subscript𝛽𝑡4\\beta\_{t}\\equiv 4 in Eq.(25) in Song et al. ( [2021b](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib71 "")) and use the same marginals to replicate the VPSDE of the Gaussian SB with αt≡0subscript𝛼𝑡0\\alpha\_{t}\\equiv 0 and ct≡−2subscript𝑐𝑡2c\_{t}\\equiv-2 in Eq.(7) in Bunne et al. ( [2023](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib7 "")). We train VSDM with 20 stages and randomly pick 256 samples for presentation. We compare the flow trajectories from both models and observe in Figure [1](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#S7.F1 "Figure 1 ‣ 7.1 Comparison to Gaussian Schrodinger Bridge ‣ 7 Empirical Studies ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models") that the ground truth solution forms an almost linear path, while our VSDM sample trajectories exhibit a consistent alignment with trajectories from Gaussian SB. We attribute the bias predominantly to score estimations and numerical discretization.

![Refer to caption](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795/assets/figures/Variational_Schrodinger_diffusion.png)(b)VSDM

Figure 1: Gaussian SB (GSB) v.s. VSDM on the flow trajectories.

### 7.2 Synthetic Data

We test our variational Schrödinger diffusion models (VSDMs) on two synthetic datasets: spiral and checkerboard (detailed in section [D.2.1](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#A4.SS2.SSS1 "D.2.1 Checkerboard Data ‣ D.2 Synthetic Data ‣ Appendix D Experimental Details ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models")). We include SGMs as the baseline models and aim to show the strength of VSDMs on general shapes with straighter trajectories. As such, we stretch the Y-axis of the spiral data by 8 times and the X-axis of the checkerboard data by 6 times and denote them by spiral-8Y and checkerboard-6X, respectively.

We adopt a monotone increasing {βn​h}n=0N−1superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝛽𝑛ℎ𝑛0𝑁1\\{\\beta\_{nh}\\}\_{n=0}^{N-1} similar to Song et al. ( [2021b](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib71 "")) and denote by βminsubscript𝛽\\beta\_{\\min} and βmaxsubscript𝛽\\beta\_{\\max} the minimum and maximum of {βn​h}n=0N−1superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝛽𝑛ℎ𝑛0𝑁1\\{\\beta\_{nh}\\}\_{n=0}^{N-1}. We fix ζ=0.75𝜁0.75\\zeta=0.75 and βmin=0.1subscript𝛽0.1\\beta\_{\\min}=0.1 and we focus on the study with different βmaxsubscript𝛽\\beta\_{\\max}. We find that SGMs work pretty well with βmax=10subscript𝛽10\\beta\_{\\max}=10 (SGM-10) on standard isotropic shapes. However, when it comes to spiral-8Y, the SGM-10 _struggles to recover_ the boundary regions on the spiral-8Y data as shown in Figure [2](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#S7.F2 "Figure 2 ‣ Generations of Anisotropic Shapes ‣ 7.2 Synthetic Data ‣ 7 Empirical Studies ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models") (top).

##### Generations of Anisotropic Shapes

To illustrate the effectiveness of our approach, Figure [2](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#S7.F2 "Figure 2 ‣ Generations of Anisotropic Shapes ‣ 7.2 Synthetic Data ‣ 7 Empirical Studies ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models") (bottom) shows that VSDM-10 accurately reconstructs the edges of the spiral and generates high-quality samples.

##### Straighter Trajectories

The SGM-10 fails to fully generate the anisotropic spiral-8Y and increasing βmaxsubscript𝛽\\beta\_{\\max} to 20 or 30 (SGM-20 and SGM-30) significantly alleviates this issue. However, we observe that excessive βmaxsubscript𝛽\\beta\_{\\max} values in SGMs compromise the straightness and leads to inefficient transport, especially in the X-axis of spiral-8Y.

![Refer to caption](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795/assets/x3.png)(a)SGM-10

![Refer to caption](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795/assets/x4.png)(b)SGM-20

![Refer to caption](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795/assets/x5.png)(c)SGM-30

Figure 3: Probability flow ODE via VSDMs and SGMs. SGM with βmax=10subscript𝛽10\\beta\_{\\max}=10 is denoted by SGM-10 for convenience.

Instead of setting excessive βmaxsubscript𝛽\\beta\_{\\max} on both axes, our VSDM-10, by contrast, proposes conservative diffusion scales on the X-axis of spiral-8Y and explores more on the Y-axis of spiral-8Y. As such, we obtain around 40% improvement on the straightness in Figure [3](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#S7.F3 "Figure 3 ‣ Straighter Trajectories ‣ 7.2 Synthetic Data ‣ 7 Empirical Studies ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models") and Table [4](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#A4.T4 "Table 4 ‣ D.2.3 Evaluation of The Straightness ‣ D.2 Synthetic Data ‣ Appendix D Experimental Details ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models").

Additional insights into a similar analysis of the checkboard dataset, convergence analysis, computational time, assessments of straightness, and evaluations via a smaller number of function evaluations (NFEs) can be found in Appendix [D.2](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#A4.SS2 "D.2 Synthetic Data ‣ Appendix D Experimental Details ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models").

##### Experiment Setup

In this experiment, we evaluate the performance of VSDM on image modeling tasks. We choose the CIFAR10 datasetas representative image data to demonstrate the scalability of the proposed VSDM on generative modeling of high-dimensional distributions. We refer to the code base of FB-SDE (Chen et al., [2022b](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib12 "")) and use the same forward diffusion process of the EDM model (Karras et al., [2022](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib32 "")). Since the training of VSDM is an alternative manner between forward and backward training, we build our implementations based on the open-source diffusion distillation code base (Luo et al., [2024a](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib47 ""))¶¶¶See code in [https://github.com/pkulwj1994/diff\_instruct](https://github.com/pkulwj1994/diff_instruct ""), which provides a high-quality empirical implementation of alternative training with EDM model on CIFAR10 data. To make the VSDM algorithm stable, we simplify the matrix 𝐃tsubscript𝐃𝑡{\\bf D}\_{t} to be diagonal with learnable diagonal elements, which is the case as we introduced in Corollary [1](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#Thmcorollary1 "Corollary 1. ‣ Speed-ups via Time-invariant and Diagonal 𝐃_𝑡 ‣ 4.2 Closed-form Expression of Backward Score ‣ 4 Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models"). We train the VSDM model from scratch on two NVIDIA A100-80G GPUs for two days and generate images from the trained VSDM with the Euler–Maruyama numerical solver with 200 discretized steps for generation.

##### Performances.

We measure the generative performances in terms of the Fretchat Inception Score (FID (Heusel et al., [2017](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib24 "")), the lower the better), which is a widely used metric for evaluating generative modeling performances.

Tables [2](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#S7.T2 "Table 2 ‣ Experiment Setup ‣ 7.3 Image Data Modeling ‣ 7 Empirical Studies ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models") summarize the FID values of VSDM along with other optimal-transport-based and score-based generative models on the CIFAR10 datasets (unconditional without labels). The VSDM outperforms other optimal transport-based models with an FID of 2.28. This demonstrates that the VSDM has applicable scalability to model high-dimensional distributions. Figure [4](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#S7.F4 "Figure 4 ‣ 7.3 Image Data Modeling ‣ 7 Empirical Studies ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models") shows some non-cherry-picked unconditional generated samples from VSDM trained on the CIFAR10 dataset.

##### Convergence Speed.

To demonstrate the convergence speed of VSDM along training processes, we record the FID values in Table [1](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#S7.T1 "Table 1 ‣ 7.3 Image Data Modeling ‣ 7 Empirical Studies ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models") for a training trail with no warmup on CIFAR10 datasets (unconditional). We use a batch size of 256 and a learning rate of 1​e−41𝑒41e-4. We use the 2nd-order Heun numerical solver to sample. The result shows that VSDM has a smooth convergence performance.

### 7.4 Time Series Forecasting

We use multivariate probabilistic forecasting as a real-world _conditional_ modeling task. Let {(t1,𝐱1),…,(tn,𝐱n)}subscript𝑡1subscript𝐱1…subscript𝑡𝑛subscript𝐱𝑛\\{(t\_{1},{\\bf x}\_{1}),\\dots,(t\_{n},{\\bf x}\_{n})\\}, 𝐱∈ℝd𝐱superscriptℝ𝑑{\\bf x}\\in\\mathbb{R}^{d}, denote a single multivariate time series. Given a dataset of such time series we want to predict the next P𝑃P values 𝐱n+1,…,𝐱n+Psubscript𝐱𝑛1…subscript𝐱𝑛𝑃{\\bf x}\_{n+1},\\dots,{\\bf x}\_{n+P}. In probabilistic modeling, we want to generate forecasts from learned p​(𝐱n+1:n+P\|𝐱1:n)𝑝conditionalsubscript𝐱:𝑛1𝑛𝑃subscript𝐱:1𝑛p({\\bf x}\_{n+1:n+P}\|{\\bf x}\_{1:n}).

The usual approach is to have an encoder that represents a sequence 𝐱1:isubscript𝐱:1𝑖{\\bf x}\_{1:i} with a fixed-sized vector 𝒉i∈ℝhsubscript𝒉𝑖superscriptℝℎ\\bm{h}\_{i}\\in\\mathbb{R}^{h}, ∀ifor-all𝑖\\forall i, and then parameterize the output distribution p​(𝐱i+1\|𝒉i)𝑝conditionalsubscript𝐱𝑖1subscript𝒉𝑖p({\\bf x}\_{i+1}\|\\bm{h}\_{i}). At inference time we encode the history into 𝒉nsubscript𝒉𝑛\\bm{h}\_{n} and sample the next value from p​(𝐱n+1\|𝒉n)𝑝conditionalsubscript𝐱𝑛1subscript𝒉𝑛p({\\bf x}\_{n+1}\|\\bm{h}\_{n}), then use 𝐱n+1subscript𝐱𝑛1{\\bf x}\_{n+1} to get the updated 𝒉n+1subscript𝒉𝑛1\\bm{h}\_{n+1} and repeat until we obtain 𝐱n+Psubscript𝐱𝑛𝑃{\\bf x}\_{n+P}.

In the previous works, the output distribution has been specified with a Copulas (Salinas et al., [2019](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib64 "")) and denoising diffusion (Rasul et al., [2021](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib60 "")). We augment our approach to allow conditional generation which requires only changing the model to include the conditioning vector 𝒉isubscript𝒉𝑖\\bm{h}\_{i}. For that we adopt the U-Net architecture. We use the LSTM neural network as a sequence encoder.

We use three real-world datasets, as described in Appendix [D.3](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#A4.SS3 "D.3 Multivariate Probabilistic Forecasting ‣ Appendix D Experimental Details ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models"). We compare to the SGM and the denoising diffusion approach from Rasul et al. ( [2021](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib60 "")) which we refer to as DDPM. Table [3](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#S7.T3 "Table 3 ‣ 7.4 Time Series Forecasting ‣ 7 Empirical Studies ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models") shows that our method matches or outperforms the competitors. Figure [5](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#S7.F5 "Figure 5 ‣ 7.4 Time Series Forecasting ‣ 7 Empirical Studies ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models") is a demo for conditional time series generation and more details are presented in Figure [12](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#A4.F12 "Figure 12 ‣ Training. ‣ D.3 Multivariate Probabilistic Forecasting ‣ Appendix D Experimental Details ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models") to demonstrate the quality of the forecasts.

## 8 Conclusions and Future Works

The Schrödinger bridge diffusion model offers a principled approach to solving optimal transport, but estimating the intractable forward score relies on implicit training through costly simulated trajectories. To address this scalability issue, we present the variational Schrödinger diffusion model (VSDM), utilizing linear variational forward scores for simulation-free training of backward score functions. Theoretical foundations leverage stochastic approximation theory, demonstrating the convergence of variational scores to local equilibrium and highlighting the variational gap in optimal transport. Empirically, VSDM showcases
the strength of generating data with anisotropic shapes and yielding the desired straighter transport paths for reducing the number of functional evaluations. VSDM also exhibits scalability in handling large-scale image datasets without requiring warm-up initializations. In future research, we aim to explore the critically damped (momentum) acceleration (Dockhorn et al., [2022](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib21 "")) and Hessian approximations to develop the “ADAM” alternative of diffusion models.

## Acknowledgements

We thank Valentin De Bortoli, Tianyang Hu, and the anonymous reviewers for their valuable insights.

## Impact Statement

This paper proposed a principled approach to accelerate the training and sampling of generative models using optimal transport. This work will contribute to developing text-to-image generation, artwork creation, and product design. However, it may also raise challenges in the fake-content generation and pose a threat to online privacy and security.

## Appendix B Stochastic Approximation

Stochastic approximation (SA), also known as the Robbins–Monro algorithm (Robbins & Monro, [1951](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib61 ""); Benveniste et al., [1990](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib5 "")) offers a conventional framework for the study of adaptive algorithms. The stochastic approximation algorithm works by repeating the sampling-optimization iterations in the dynamic setting in terms of simulated trajectories. We present our algorithm in Algorithm [2](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#alg2 "Algorithm 2 ‣ Appendix B Stochastic Approximation ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models").

Algorithm 2 The (dynamic) stochastic approximation (SA) algorithm. The (dynamic) SA is a theoretical formulation of Algorithm [1](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#alg1 "Algorithm 1 ‣ 4.2.2 Probability Flow ODE ‣ 4.2 Closed-form Expression of Backward Score ‣ 4 Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models"). We assume optimizing the loss function ( [16](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#S4.E16 "Equation 16 ‣ 4.2 Closed-form Expression of Backward Score ‣ 4 Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models")) yields proper score estimations st(k+1)subscriptsuperscript𝑠𝑘1𝑡s^{(k+1)}\_{t} at each stage k𝑘k and time t𝑡t to approximate ∇log⁡ρ→t(k)​(𝐱→t\|𝐱→0)∇superscriptsubscript→𝜌𝑡𝑘conditionalsubscript→𝐱𝑡subscript→𝐱0\\nabla\\log\\overrightarrow{\\rho}\_{t}^{(k)}(\\overrightarrow{{\\bf x}}\_{t}\|\\overrightarrow{{\\bf x}}\_{0}) in Eq.( [9b](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#S4.E9.2 "Equation 9b ‣ Equation 9 ‣ 4.1 Variational Inference via Linear Approximation ‣ 4 Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models")).

Since the samples simulated from ρ←tsubscript←𝜌𝑡\\overleftarrow{\\rho}\_{t} are slightly biased due to the convergence of forward process, discretization error, and score estimation errors as shown in Theorem [1](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#Thmtheorem1 "Theorem 1 (Generation quality). ‣ B.1 Convergence of Approximated Samples with a Fixed 𝐀_𝑡 ‣ Appendix B Stochastic Approximation ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models"). We expect the mean field is also biased with a perturbed equilibrium. However, by the perturbation theory (Vanden-Eijnden, [2001](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib76 "")), the perturbation is mild and controlled by the errors in Theorem [1](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#Thmtheorem1 "Theorem 1 (Generation quality). ‣ B.1 Convergence of Approximated Samples with a Fixed 𝐀_𝑡 ‣ Appendix B Stochastic Approximation ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models"). Hence although 𝐀t⋆superscriptsubscript𝐀𝑡⋆{\\mathrm{\\mathbf{A}}}\_{t}^{\\star} is not the optimal linear solution in terms of optimal transport, it still yields efficient transportation plans.

Since the exclusive (reverse) KL divergence is known to approximate a single mode (denoted by 𝐀t⋆superscriptsubscript𝐀𝑡⋆{\\mathrm{\\mathbf{A}}}\_{t}^{\\star}) in fitting multi-modal distributions, we proceed to assume the following regularity conditions for the solution 𝐀t⋆superscriptsubscript𝐀𝑡⋆{\\mathrm{\\mathbf{A}}}\_{t}^{\\star} and the neighborhood of 𝐀t⋆superscriptsubscript𝐀𝑡⋆{\\mathrm{\\mathbf{A}}}\_{t}^{\\star}.

### B.2 Part II: Stochastic Approximation Convergence

The convergence of samples based on the adaptive algorithms is slightly weaker than the standard one due to the adaptive update, but this is necessary because 𝐀t⋆superscriptsubscript𝐀𝑡⋆{\\mathrm{\\mathbf{A}}}\_{t}^{\\star} is more transport efficient than a vanilla 𝐀tsubscript𝐀𝑡{\\mathrm{\\mathbf{A}}}\_{t}.

∎

## Appendix D Experimental Details

### D.1 Parametrization of the Variational Score

For the general transport, there is no closed-form update and we adopt an SVD decomposition with time embeddings to learn the linear dynamics in Figure [6](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#A4.F6 "Figure 6 ‣ D.1 Parametrization of the Variational Score ‣ Appendix D Experimental Details ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models"). The number of parameters is reduced by thousands of times, which have greatly reduced the training variance (Grathwohl et al., [2019](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib23 "")).

![Refer to caption](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795/assets/figures/linear_module2.png)Figure 6: Architecture of the linear module. Both U𝑈U and V𝑉V are orthogonal matrices and ΛΛ\\Lambda denotes the singular values.

### D.2 Synthetic Data

#### D.2.1 Checkerboard Data

The generation of the checkerboard data is presented in Figure. [7](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#A4.F7 "Figure 7 ‣ D.2.1 Checkerboard Data ‣ D.2 Synthetic Data ‣ Appendix D Experimental Details ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models"). The probability path is presented in Figure. [8](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#A4.F8 "Figure 8 ‣ D.2.1 Checkerboard Data ‣ D.2 Synthetic Data ‣ Appendix D Experimental Details ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models"). The conclusion is similar to the spiral data.

![Refer to caption](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795/assets/x7.png)

![Refer to caption](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795/assets/x8.png)

Figure 7: Variational Schrödinger diffusion models (VSDMs, right) v.s. SGMs (left) with the same hyperparameters (βmax=10subscript𝛽10\\beta\_{\\max}=10).

![Refer to caption](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795/assets/x9.png)(a)SGM-10

![Refer to caption](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795/assets/x10.png)(b)SGM-20

Figure 8: Probability flow ODE via VSDMs and SGMs. SGM with βmax=10subscript𝛽10\\beta\_{\\max}=10 is denoted by SGM-10 for convenience.

#### D.2.2 Convergence and Computational Time

##### Convergence Study

Under the same setup, VSDM-10 adaptively learns 𝐀tsubscript𝐀𝑡{\\mathrm{\\mathbf{A}}}\_{t} (and 𝐃tsubscript𝐃𝑡{\\bf D}\_{t}) on the fly and adapts through the pathological geometry via optimal transport. For the spiral-8Y data, the Y-axis of the singular values of 𝐃tsubscript𝐃𝑡{\\bf D}\_{t} (scaled by βmaxsubscript𝛽\\beta\_{\\max}) converges from 10 to around 19 as shown in Figure [9](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#A4.F9 "Figure 9 ‣ Convergence Study ‣ D.2.2 Convergence and Computational Time ‣ D.2 Synthetic Data ‣ Appendix D Experimental Details ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models"). The singular value of the X-axis quickly converges from 10 to a conservative scale of 7. We also tried VSDM-20 and found that both the Y-axis and X-axis converge to similar scales, which justifies the stability.

![Refer to caption](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795/assets/figures/spiral_lambda.png)(a)Spiral-8Y

![Refer to caption](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795/assets/figures/num_itr_vs_time.png)(b)Convergence v.s. time

![Refer to caption](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795/assets/figures/check_lambda.png)(c)Checkboard-6X

Figure 9: Optimization of 𝚲𝚲{\\boldsymbol{\\Lambda}} of 𝐃𝐃{\\bf D} scaled by βmaxsubscript𝛽\\beta\_{\\max} (scaled lambda of 𝐃𝐃{\\bf D}) of VSDM-10 and VSDM-20.

##### Computational Time

We tried different budgets to train the variational scores and observed in Figure [9](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#A4.F9 "Figure 9 ‣ Convergence Study ‣ D.2.2 Convergence and Computational Time ‣ D.2 Synthetic Data ‣ Appendix D Experimental Details ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models")(b) that 300 iterations yield the fastest convergence among the 4 choices but also lead to 23% extra time compared to SGM. Reducing the number of iterations impacts convergence minimally due to the linearity of the variational scores and significantly reduces the training time.

#### D.2.3 Evaluation of The Straightness

Straighter trajectories lead to a smaller number of functional evaluations (NFEs). In section [D.2.3](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#A4.SS2.SSS3 "D.2.3 Evaluation of The Straightness ‣ D.2 Synthetic Data ‣ Appendix D Experimental Details ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models"), we compare VSDM-20 with SGM-20 with NFE=6 and NFE=8 using the same computational budget and observe in Figure [10](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#A4.F10 "Figure 10 ‣ D.2.4 A Smaller Number of Function Evaluations ‣ D.2 Synthetic Data ‣ Appendix D Experimental Details ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models") and [11](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#A4.F11 "Figure 11 ‣ D.2.4 A Smaller Number of Function Evaluations ‣ D.2 Synthetic Data ‣ Appendix D Experimental Details ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models") the superiority of the VSDM model in generating more details.

To evaluate the straightness of the probability flow ODE, similar in spirit to Pooladian et al. ( [2023](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib58 "")), we define our straightness metric by approximating the second derivative of the probability flow ( [18](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#S4.E18 "Equation 18 ‣ 4.2.2 Probability Flow ODE ‣ 4.2 Closed-form Expression of Backward Score ‣ 4 Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models")) as follows

|     |     |     |     |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
|  | S​(i)=∫0T𝔼𝐱←t∼ρ←t​\[\|d2​𝐱←t​(i)d​t2\|\]​dt,S𝑖superscriptsubscript0𝑇subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript←𝐱𝑡subscript←𝜌𝑡delimited-\[\]superscriptd2subscript←𝐱𝑡𝑖dsuperscript𝑡2differential-d𝑡\\begin{split}\\text{S}(i)&=\\int\_{0}^{T}\\mathbb{E}\_{\\overleftarrow{{\\bf x}}\_{t}\\sim\\overleftarrow{\\rho}\_{t}}\\bigg{\[}\\bigg{\|}\\frac{\\mathrm{d}^{2}\\overleftarrow{{\\bf x}}\_{t}(i)}{\\mathrm{d}t^{2}}\\bigg{\|}\\bigg{\]}\\mathrm{d}t,\\\<br>\\end{split} |  | (38) |

where i∈{1,2}𝑖12i\\in\\{1,2\\}, 𝐱←t​(1)subscript←𝐱𝑡1\\overleftarrow{{\\bf x}}\_{t}(1) and 𝐱←t​(2)subscript←𝐱𝑡2\\overleftarrow{{\\bf x}}\_{t}(2) denote the X-axis and Y-axis, respectively. S≥0𝑆0S\\geq 0 and S=0𝑆0S=0 only when the transport is a straight path.

We report the straightness in Table [4](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#A4.T4 "Table 4 ‣ D.2.3 Evaluation of The Straightness ‣ D.2 Synthetic Data ‣ Appendix D Experimental Details ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models") and find the improvement of VSDM-10 over SGM-20 and SGM-30 is around 40%. We also tried VSDM-20 on both datasets and found a significant improvement over the baseline SGM methods. However, despite the consistent convergence in Figure [9](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#A4.F9 "Figure 9 ‣ Convergence Study ‣ D.2.2 Convergence and Computational Time ‣ D.2 Synthetic Data ‣ Appendix D Experimental Details ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models"), we found VSDM-20 still performs slightly worse than VSDM-10, which implies the potential to tune βmaxsubscript𝛽\\beta\_{\\max} to further enhance the performance.

Table 4: Straightness metric defined in Eq.( [38](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#A4.E38 "Equation 38 ‣ D.2.3 Evaluation of The Straightness ‣ D.2 Synthetic Data ‣ Appendix D Experimental Details ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models")) via SGMs and VSDM with different βmaxsubscript𝛽\\beta\_{\\max}’s. SGM with βmax=10subscript𝛽10\\beta\_{\\max}=10 (SGM-10) fails to generate data of anisotropic shapes and is not reported.

| Straightness (X / Y) | Spiral-8Y | Checkerboard-6X |
| SGM-20 | 8.3 / 49.3 | 53.5 / 11.0 |
| SGM-30 | 9.4 / 57.3 | 64.6 / 13.1 |
| VSDM-20 | 6.3 / 45.6 | 49.4 /    7.4 |
| VSDM-10 | 5.5 / 38.7 | 43.9 /    6.5 |

#### D.2.4 A Smaller Number of Function Evaluations

We also compare our VSDM-20 with SGM-20 based on a small number of function evaluations (NFE). We use probability flow to conduct the experiments and choose a uniform time grid for convenience. We find that both models cannot fully generate the desired data with NFE=6 in Figure [10](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#A4.F10 "Figure 10 ‣ D.2.4 A Smaller Number of Function Evaluations ‣ D.2 Synthetic Data ‣ Appendix D Experimental Details ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models") and VSDM appears to recover more details, especially on the top and bottom of the spiral. For the checkboard data, both models work nicely under the same setting and we cannot see a visual difference. With NFE=8 in Figure [11](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#A4.F11 "Figure 11 ‣ D.2.4 A Smaller Number of Function Evaluations ‣ D.2 Synthetic Data ‣ Appendix D Experimental Details ‣ Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models"), we observe that our VSDM-20 works remarkably well on both datasets and is slightly superior to SGM-20 in generating the corner details.

### D.3 Multivariate Probabilistic Forecasting

##### Data.

We use publicly available datasets. Exchange rate has 6071 8-dimensional measurements and a daily frequency. The goal is to predict the value over the next 30 days. Solar is an hourly 137-dimensional dataset with 7009 values. Electricity is also hourly, with 370 dimensions and 5833 measurements. For both, we predict the values over the next day.

##### Training.

We adopt the encoder-decoder architecture as described in the main text, and change the decoder to either our generative model or one of the competitors. The encoder is an LSTM with 2 layers and a hidden dimension size 64. We train the model for 200 epochs, where each epoch takes 50 model updates. In case of our model we also alternate between two training directions at a predefined rate. The neural network parameterizing the backward direction has the same hyperparameters as in (Rasul et al., [2021](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795#bib.bib60 "")), that is, it has 8 layers, 8 channels, and a hidden dimension of 64. The DDPM baseline uses a standard setting for the linear beta-scheduler: βmin=0.0001subscript𝛽min0.0001\\beta\_{\\text{min}}=0.0001, βmax=0.1subscript𝛽max0.1\\beta\_{\\text{max}}=0.1 and 150 steps.

![Refer to caption](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795/assets/x21.png)

![Refer to caption](https://ar5iv.labs.arxiv.org/html/2405.04795/assets/x22.png)

Figure 12: Example forecasts for Electricity (top), Exchange (middle), and Solar (bottom) datasets using our VSDM model. We show 3 out of 370, 8, and 137 dimensions, respectively.

metadata.title: [2405.04795] Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models

html:
Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models

Wei Deng    Weijian Luo    Yixin Tan    Marin Biloš    Yu Chen    Yuriy Nevmyvaka    Ricky T. Q. Chen
Abstract

Schrödinger bridge (SB) has emerged as the go-to method for optimizing transportation plans in diffusion models. However, SB requires estimating the intractable forward score functions, inevitably resulting in the costly implicit training loss based on simulated trajectories. To improve the scalability while preserving efficient transportation plans, we leverage variational inference to linearize the forward score functions (variational scores) of SB and restore simulation-free properties in training backward scores. We propose the variational Schrödinger diffusion model (VSDM), where the forward process is a multivariate diffusion and the variational scores are adaptively optimized for efficient transport. Theoretically, we use stochastic approximation to prove the convergence of the variational scores and show the convergence of the adaptively generated samples based on the optimal variational scores. Empirically, we test the algorithm in simulated examples and observe that VSDM is efficient in generations of anisotropic shapes and yields straighter sample trajectories compared to the single-variate diffusion. We also verify the scalability of the algorithm in real-world data and achieve competitive unconditional generation performance in CIFAR10 and conditional generation in time series modeling. Notably, VSDM no longer depends on warm-up initializations and has become tuning-friendly in training large-scale experiments.

Machine Learning, ICML

1 Introduction

Diffusion models have showcased remarkable proficiency across diverse domains, spanning large-scale generations of image, video, and audio, conditional text-to-image tasks, and adversarial defenses (Dhariwal & Nichol, 2022; Ho et al., 2022; Kong et al., 2021; Ramesh et al., 2022; Zhang et al., 2024). The key to their scalability lies in the closed-form updates of the forward process, highlighting both statistical efficiency (Koehler et al., 2023) and diminished dependence on dimensionality (Vono et al., 2022). Nevertheless, diffusion models lack a distinct guarantee of optimal transport (OT) properties (Lavenant & Santambrogio, 2022) and often necessitate costly evaluations to generate higher-fidelity content (Ho et al., 2020; Salimans & Ho, 2022; Lu et al., 2022; Xue et al., 2023; Luo, 2023).

Alternatively, the Schrödinger bridge (SB) problem (Léonard, 2014; Chen & Georgiou, 2016; Pavon et al., 2021; Caluya & Halder, 2022; De Bortoli et al., 2021), initially rooted in quantum mechanics (Léonard, 2014), proposes optimizing a stochastic control objective through the use of forward-backward stochastic differential equations (FB-SDEs) (Chen et al., 2022b). The alternating solver gives rise to the iterative proportional fitting (IPF) algorithm (Kullback, 1968; Ruschendorf, 1995) in dynamic optimal transport (Villani, 2003; Peyré & Cuturi, 2019). Notably, the intractable forward score function plays a crucial role in providing theoretical guarantees in optimal transport (Chen et al., 2023c; Deng et al., 2024). However, it simultaneously sacrifices the simulation-free property and largely relies on warm-up checkpoints for conducting large-scale experiments (De Bortoli et al., 2021; Chen et al., 2022b). A natural follow-up question arises:

Can we train diffusion models with efficient transport?

To this end, we introduce the variational Schrödinger diffusion model (VSDM). Employing variational inference (Blei et al., 2017), we perform a locally linear approximation of the forward score function, and denote it by the variational score. The resulting linear forward stochastic differential equations (SDEs) naturally provide a closed-form update, significantly enhancing scalability. Compared to the single-variate score-based generative model (SGM), VSDM is a multivariate diffusion (Singhal et al., 2023). Moreover, hyperparameters are adaptively optimized for more efficient transportation plans within the Schrödinger bridge framework (Chen et al., 2022b).

Theoretically, we leverage stochastic approximation (Robbins & Monro, 1951) to demonstrate the convergence of the variational score to the optimal local estimators. Although the global transport optimality is compromised, the notable simulation-free speed-ups in training the backward score render the algorithm particularly attractive for training various generation tasks from scratch. Additionally, the efficiency of simulation-based training for the linearized variational score significantly improves owing to computational advancements in convex optimization. We validate the strength of VSDM through simulations, achieving compelling performance on standard image generation tasks. Our contributions unfold in four key aspects:

  • •

    We introduce the variational Schrödinger diffusion model (VSDM), a multivariate diffusion with optimal variational scores guided by optimal transport. Additionally, the training of backward scores is simulation-free and becomes much more scalable.

  • •

    We study the convergence of the variational score using stochastic approximation (SA) theory, which can be further generalized to a class of state space diffusion models for future developments.

  • •

    VSDM is effective in generating data of anisotropic shapes and motivates straighter transportation paths via the optimized transport.

  • •

    VSDM achieves competitive unconditional generation on CIFAR10 and conditional generation in time series modeling without reliance on warm-up initializations.

2 Related Works

Flow Matching and Beyond

Lipman et al. (2023) utilized the McCann displacement interpolation (McCann, 1997) to train simulation-free CNFs to encourage straight trajectories. Consequently, Pooladian et al. (2023); Tong et al. (2023) proposed straightening by using minibatch optimal transport solutions. Similar ideas were achieved by Liu (2022); Liu et al. (2023) to iteratively rectify the interpolation path. Albergo & Vanden-Eijnden (2023); Albergo et al. (2023) developed the stochastic interpolant approach to unify both flow and diffusion models. However, “straighter” transport maps may not imply optimal transportation plans in general and the couplings are still not effectively optimized.

Dynamic Optimal Transport

Finlay et al. (2020); Onken et al. (2021) introduced additional regularization through optimal transport to enforce straighter trajectories in CNFs and reduce the computational cost. De Bortoli et al. (2021); Chen et al. (2022b); Vargas et al. (2021) studied the dynamic Schrödinger bridge with guarantees in entropic optimal transport (EOT) (Chen et al., 2023c); Shi et al. (2023); Peluchetti (2023); Chen et al. (2023b) generalized bridge matching and flow matching based EOT and obtained smoother trajectories, however, scalability remains a significant concern for Schrödinger-based diffusions.

4 Variational Schrödinger Diffusion Models

SB outperforms SGMs in the theoretical potential of optimal transport and an intractable score function ∇log⁡ψ→t​(𝐱t)∇subscript→𝜓𝑡subscript𝐱𝑡\nabla\log\overrightarrow{\psi}_{t}({\bf x}_{t}) is exploited in the forward SDE for more efficient transportation plans. However, there is no free lunch in achieving such efficiency, and it comes with three notable downsides:

  • •

    Solving ∇log⁡ψ→t∇subscript→𝜓𝑡\nabla\log\overrightarrow{\psi}_{t} in Eq.(5a) for optimal transport is prohibitively costly and may not be necessary (Marzouk et al., 2016; Liu et al., 2023).

  • •

    The nonlinear diffusion no longer yields closed-form expression of 𝐱→tsubscript→𝐱𝑡\overrightarrow{{\bf x}}_{t} given 𝐱→0subscript→𝐱0\overrightarrow{{\bf x}}_{0} (Chen et al., 2022b).

  • •

    The ISM loss is inevitable and the estimator suffers from a large variance issue (Hutchinson, 1989).

The stochastic approximation algorithm is a standard framework to study adaptive sampling algorithms (Liang et al., 2007). 𝐀¯n​h(k)=∑i=1k𝐀n​h(i)=(1−1k)​𝐀¯n​h(k−1)+1k​𝐀n​h(k),superscriptsubscript¯𝐀𝑛ℎ𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐀𝑛ℎ𝑖11𝑘superscriptsubscript¯𝐀𝑛ℎ𝑘11𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐀𝑛ℎ𝑘\overline{{\mathrm{\mathbf{A}}}}_{nh}^{(k)}=\sum_{i=1}^{k}{\mathrm{\mathbf{A}}}_{nh}^{(i)}=\bigg{(}1-\frac{1}{k}\bigg{)}\overline{{\mathrm{\mathbf{A}}}}_{nh}^{(k-1)}+\frac{1}{k}{\mathrm{\mathbf{A}}}_{nh}^{(k)},

where 𝐀¯n​h(k)superscriptsubscript¯𝐀𝑛ℎ𝑘\overline{{\mathrm{\mathbf{A}}}}_{nh}^{(k)} is known to be an asymptotically efficient (optimal) estimator (Polyak & Juditsky, 1992) in the local state space 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} by assumption A1.

Exponential Moving Average (EMA)

Despite guarantees in convex scenarios, the parameter space differs tremendously in different surfaces in non-convex state space 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}. Empirically, if we want to exploit information from multiple modes, a standard extension is to employ the EMA technique (Trivedi & Kondor, 2017):

𝐀¯n​h(k)=(1−η)​𝐀¯n​h(k−1)+η​𝐀n​h(k),where ​η∈(0,1).formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript¯𝐀𝑛ℎ𝑘1𝜂superscriptsubscript¯𝐀𝑛ℎ𝑘1𝜂superscriptsubscript𝐀𝑛ℎ𝑘where 𝜂01\overline{{\mathrm{\mathbf{A}}}}_{nh}^{(k)}=(1-\eta)\overline{{\mathrm{\mathbf{A}}}}_{nh}^{(k-1)}+\eta{\mathrm{\mathbf{A}}}_{nh}^{(k)},\text{where }\eta\in(0,1).

The EMA techniques are widely used empirically in diffusion models and Schrödinger bridge (Song & Ermon, 2020; De Bortoli et al., 2021; Chen et al., 2022b) to avoid oscillating trajectories. Now we are ready to present our methodology in Algorithm 1.

Computational Cost

Regarding the wall-clock computational time: i) training (linear) variational scores, albeit in a simulation-based manner, becomes significantly faster than estimating nonlinear forward scores in Schrödinger bridge; ii) the variational parametrization greatly reduced the number of model parameters, which yields a much-reduced variance in the Hutchinson’s estimator (Hutchinson, 1989); iii) since we don’t need to update 𝐀tsubscript𝐀𝑡{\mathrm{\mathbf{A}}}_{t} as often as the backward score model, we can further amortize the training of 𝐀tsubscript𝐀𝑡{\mathrm{\mathbf{A}}}_{t}. In the simulation example in Figure.9(b), VSDM is only 10% slower than the SGM with the same training complexity of backward scores while still maintaining efficient convergence of variational scores.

Connections to Gaussian Schrödinger bridge (GSB)

When data follows a Gaussian distribution, VSDM approximates the closed-form OT solution of Schrödinger bridge (Janati et al., 2020; Bunne et al., 2023). We refer readers to Theorem 3 (Bunne et al., 2023) for the detailed transportation plans. Compared to the vanilla 𝐀t≡𝟎subscript𝐀𝑡0{\mathrm{\mathbf{A}}}_{t}\equiv\bm{0}, we can significantly reduce the variational gap with KL​(L∥L⋆)KLconditionalLsuperscriptL⋆\mathrm{KL}({\mathrm{L}}\|{\mathrm{L}}^{\star}) using proper parametrization and sufficient training.

We briefly compare VSDM to SGM and SB in the following:

7 Empirical Studies

7.1 Comparison to Gaussian Schrodinger Bridge

VSDM is approximating GSB (Bunne et al., 2023) when both marginals are Gaussian distributions. To evaluate the solutions, we run our VSDM with a fixed βt≡4subscript𝛽𝑡4\beta_{t}\equiv 4 in Eq.(25) in Song et al. (2021b) and use the same marginals to replicate the VPSDE of the Gaussian SB with αt≡0subscript𝛼𝑡0\alpha_{t}\equiv 0 and ct≡−2subscript𝑐𝑡2c_{t}\equiv-2 in Eq.(7) in Bunne et al. (2023). We train VSDM with 20 stages and randomly pick 256 samples for presentation. We compare the flow trajectories from both models and observe in Figure 1 that the ground truth solution forms an almost linear path, while our VSDM sample trajectories exhibit a consistent alignment with trajectories from Gaussian SB. We attribute the bias predominantly to score estimations and numerical discretization.

7.2 Synthetic Data

We test our variational Schrödinger diffusion models (VSDMs) on two synthetic datasets: spiral and checkerboard (detailed in section D.2.1). We include SGMs as the baseline models and aim to show the strength of VSDMs on general shapes with straighter trajectories. As such, we stretch the Y-axis of the spiral data by 8 times and the X-axis of the checkerboard data by 6 times and denote them by spiral-8Y and checkerboard-6X, respectively.

We adopt a monotone increasing {βn​h}n=0N−1superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝛽𝑛ℎ𝑛0𝑁1\{\beta_{nh}\}_{n=0}^{N-1} similar to Song et al. (2021b) and denote by βminsubscript𝛽\beta_{\min} and βmaxsubscript𝛽\beta_{\max} the minimum and maximum of {βn​h}n=0N−1superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝛽𝑛ℎ𝑛0𝑁1\{\beta_{nh}\}_{n=0}^{N-1}. We fix ζ=0.75𝜁0.75\zeta=0.75 and βmin=0.1subscript𝛽0.1\beta_{\min}=0.1 and we focus on the study with different βmaxsubscript𝛽\beta_{\max}. We find that SGMs work pretty well with βmax=10subscript𝛽10\beta_{\max}=10 (SGM-10) on standard isotropic shapes. However, when it comes to spiral-8Y, the SGM-10 struggles to recover the boundary regions on the spiral-8Y data as shown in Figure 2 (top).

Generations of Anisotropic Shapes

To illustrate the effectiveness of our approach, Figure 2 (bottom) shows that VSDM-10 accurately reconstructs the edges of the spiral and generates high-quality samples.

Straighter Trajectories

The SGM-10 fails to fully generate the anisotropic spiral-8Y and increasing βmaxsubscript𝛽\beta_{\max} to 20 or 30 (SGM-20 and SGM-30) significantly alleviates this issue. However, we observe that excessive βmaxsubscript𝛽\beta_{\max} values in SGMs compromise the straightness and leads to inefficient transport, especially in the X-axis of spiral-8Y.

Instead of setting excessive βmaxsubscript𝛽\beta_{\max} on both axes, our VSDM-10, by contrast, proposes conservative diffusion scales on the X-axis of spiral-8Y and explores more on the Y-axis of spiral-8Y. As such, we obtain around 40% improvement on the straightness in Figure 3 and Table 4.

Additional insights into a similar analysis of the checkboard dataset, convergence analysis, computational time, assessments of straightness, and evaluations via a smaller number of function evaluations (NFEs) can be found in Appendix D.2.

7.3 Image Data Modeling

Experiment Setup

In this experiment, we evaluate the performance of VSDM on image modeling tasks. We choose the CIFAR10 datasetas representative image data to demonstrate the scalability of the proposed VSDM on generative modeling of high-dimensional distributions. We refer to the code base of FB-SDE (Chen et al., 2022b) and use the same forward diffusion process of the EDM model (Karras et al., 2022). Since the training of VSDM is an alternative manner between forward and backward training, we build our implementations based on the open-source diffusion distillation code base (Luo et al., 2024a) ¶¶¶See code in https://github.com/pkulwj1994/diff_instruct, which provides a high-quality empirical implementation of alternative training with EDM model on CIFAR10 data. To make the VSDM algorithm stable, we simplify the matrix 𝐃tsubscript𝐃𝑡{\bf D}_{t} to be diagonal with learnable diagonal elements, which is the case as we introduced in Corollary 1. We train the VSDM model from scratch on two NVIDIA A100-80G GPUs for two days and generate images from the trained VSDM with the Euler–Maruyama numerical solver with 200 discretized steps for generation.

Performances.

We measure the generative performances in terms of the Fretchat Inception Score (FID (Heusel et al., 2017), the lower the better), which is a widely used metric for evaluating generative modeling performances.

Tables 2 summarize the FID values of VSDM along with other optimal-transport-based and score-based generative models on the CIFAR10 datasets (unconditional without labels). The VSDM outperforms other optimal transport-based models with an FID of 2.28. This demonstrates that the VSDM has applicable scalability to model high-dimensional distributions. Figure 4 shows some non-cherry-picked unconditional generated samples from VSDM trained on the CIFAR10 dataset.

Convergence Speed.

To demonstrate the convergence speed of VSDM along training processes, we record the FID values in Table 1 for a training trail with no warmup on CIFAR10 datasets (unconditional). We use a batch size of 256 and a learning rate of 1​e−41𝑒41e-4. We use the 2nd-order Heun numerical solver to sample. The result shows that VSDM has a smooth convergence performance.

7.4 Time Series Forecasting

We use multivariate probabilistic forecasting as a real-world conditional modeling task. Let {(t1,𝐱1),…,(tn,𝐱n)}subscript𝑡1subscript𝐱1…subscript𝑡𝑛subscript𝐱𝑛\{(t_{1},{\bf x}_{1}),\dots,(t_{n},{\bf x}_{n})\}, 𝐱∈ℝd𝐱superscriptℝ𝑑{\bf x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, denote a single multivariate time series. Given a dataset of such time series we want to predict the next P𝑃P values 𝐱n+1,…,𝐱n+Psubscript𝐱𝑛1…subscript𝐱𝑛𝑃{\bf x}_{n+1},\dots,{\bf x}_{n+P}. In probabilistic modeling, we want to generate forecasts from learned p​(𝐱n+1:n+P|𝐱1:n)𝑝conditionalsubscript𝐱:𝑛1𝑛𝑃subscript𝐱:1𝑛p({\bf x}_{n+1:n+P}|{\bf x}_{1:n}).

The usual approach is to have an encoder that represents a sequence 𝐱1:isubscript𝐱:1𝑖{\bf x}_{1:i} with a fixed-sized vector 𝒉i∈ℝhsubscript𝒉𝑖superscriptℝℎ\bm{h}_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{h}, ∀ifor-all𝑖\forall i, and then parameterize the output distribution p​(𝐱i+1|𝒉i)𝑝conditionalsubscript𝐱𝑖1subscript𝒉𝑖p({\bf x}_{i+1}|\bm{h}_{i}). At inference time we encode the history into 𝒉nsubscript𝒉𝑛\bm{h}_{n} and sample the next value from p​(𝐱n+1|𝒉n)𝑝conditionalsubscript𝐱𝑛1subscript𝒉𝑛p({\bf x}_{n+1}|\bm{h}_{n}), then use 𝐱n+1subscript𝐱𝑛1{\bf x}_{n+1} to get the updated 𝒉n+1subscript𝒉𝑛1\bm{h}_{n+1} and repeat until we obtain 𝐱n+Psubscript𝐱𝑛𝑃{\bf x}_{n+P}.

In the previous works, the output distribution has been specified with a Copulas (Salinas et al., 2019) and denoising diffusion (Rasul et al., 2021). We augment our approach to allow conditional generation which requires only changing the model to include the conditioning vector 𝒉isubscript𝒉𝑖\bm{h}_{i}. For that we adopt the U-Net architecture. We use the LSTM neural network as a sequence encoder.

We use three real-world datasets, as described in Appendix D.3. We compare to the SGM and the denoising diffusion approach from Rasul et al. (2021) which we refer to as DDPM. Table 3 shows that our method matches or outperforms the competitors. Figure 5 is a demo for conditional time series generation and more details are presented in Figure 12 to demonstrate the quality of the forecasts.

8 Conclusions and Future Works

The Schrödinger bridge diffusion model offers a principled approach to solving optimal transport, but estimating the intractable forward score relies on implicit training through costly simulated trajectories. To address this scalability issue, we present the variational Schrödinger diffusion model (VSDM), utilizing linear variational forward scores for simulation-free training of backward score functions. Theoretical foundations leverage stochastic approximation theory, demonstrating the convergence of variational scores to local equilibrium and highlighting the variational gap in optimal transport. Empirically, VSDM showcases the strength of generating data with anisotropic shapes and yielding the desired straighter transport paths for reducing the number of functional evaluations. VSDM also exhibits scalability in handling large-scale image datasets without requiring warm-up initializations. In future research, we aim to explore the critically damped (momentum) acceleration (Dockhorn et al., 2022) and Hessian approximations to develop the “ADAM” alternative of diffusion models.

Acknowledgements

We thank Valentin De Bortoli, Tianyang Hu, and the anonymous reviewers for their valuable insights.

Impact Statement

This paper proposed a principled approach to accelerate the training and sampling of generative models using optimal transport. This work will contribute to developing text-to-image generation, artwork creation, and product design. However, it may also raise challenges in the fake-content generation and pose a threat to online privacy and security.

Appendix B Stochastic Approximation

Stochastic approximation (SA), also known as the Robbins–Monro algorithm (Robbins & Monro, 1951; Benveniste et al., 1990) offers a conventional framework for the study of adaptive algorithms. The stochastic approximation algorithm works by repeating the sampling-optimization iterations in the dynamic setting in terms of simulated trajectories. We present our algorithm in Algorithm 2.

To facilitate the analysis, we assume we only make a one-step sampling in Eq.(23). Note that it is not required in practice and multiple-step extensions can be employed to exploit the cached data more efficiently. The theoretical extension is straightforward and omitted in the proof. We also slightly abuse the notation for convenience and generalize 𝐀n​hsubscript𝐀𝑛ℎ{\mathrm{\mathbf{A}}}_{nh} to 𝐀tsubscript𝐀𝑡{\mathrm{\mathbf{A}}}_{t}.

Theoretically, the primary objective is to show the iterates (19) follow the trajectories of the dynamical system asymptotically:

B.1 Convergence of Approximated Samples with a Fixed 𝐀tsubscript𝐀𝑡{\mathrm{\mathbf{A}}}_{t}

Appendix D Experimental Details

D.1 Parametrization of the Variational Score

For the general transport, there is no closed-form update and we adopt an SVD decomposition with time embeddings to learn the linear dynamics in Figure 6. The number of parameters is reduced by thousands of times, which have greatly reduced the training variance (Grathwohl et al., 2019).

D.2 Synthetic Data

D.2.1 Checkerboard Data

The generation of the checkerboard data is presented in Figure. 7. The probability path is presented in Figure. 8. The conclusion is similar to the spiral data.

D.2.2 Convergence and Computational Time

Convergence Study

Under the same setup, VSDM-10 adaptively learns 𝐀tsubscript𝐀𝑡{\mathrm{\mathbf{A}}}_{t} (and 𝐃tsubscript𝐃𝑡{\bf D}_{t}) on the fly and adapts through the pathological geometry via optimal transport. For the spiral-8Y data, the Y-axis of the singular values of 𝐃tsubscript𝐃𝑡{\bf D}_{t} (scaled by βmaxsubscript𝛽\beta_{\max}) converges from 10 to around 19 as shown in Figure 9. The singular value of the X-axis quickly converges from 10 to a conservative scale of 7. We also tried VSDM-20 and found that both the Y-axis and X-axis converge to similar scales, which justifies the stability.

Computational Time

We tried different budgets to train the variational scores and observed in Figure 9(b) that 300 iterations yield the fastest convergence among the 4 choices but also lead to 23% extra time compared to SGM. Reducing the number of iterations impacts convergence minimally due to the linearity of the variational scores and significantly reduces the training time.

D.2.3 Evaluation of The Straightness

Straighter trajectories lead to a smaller number of functional evaluations (NFEs). In section D.2.3, we compare VSDM-20 with SGM-20 with NFE=6 and NFE=8 using the same computational budget and observe in Figure 10 and 11 the superiority of the VSDM model in generating more details.

To evaluate the straightness of the probability flow ODE, similar in spirit to Pooladian et al. (2023), we define our straightness metric by approximating the second derivative of the probability flow (18) as follows

S​(i)=∫0T𝔼𝐱←t∼ρ←t​[|d2​𝐱←t​(i)d​t2|]​dt,S𝑖superscriptsubscript0𝑇subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript←𝐱𝑡subscript←𝜌𝑡delimited-[]superscriptd2subscript←𝐱𝑡𝑖dsuperscript𝑡2differential-d𝑡\begin{split}\text{S}(i)&=\int_{0}^{T}\mathbb{E}_{\overleftarrow{{\bf x}}_{t}\sim\overleftarrow{\rho}_{t}}\bigg{[}\bigg{|}\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2}\overleftarrow{{\bf x}}_{t}(i)}{\mathrm{d}t^{2}}\bigg{|}\bigg{]}\mathrm{d}t,\\ \end{split} (38)

where i∈{1,2}𝑖12i\in\{1,2\}, 𝐱←t​(1)subscript←𝐱𝑡1\overleftarrow{{\bf x}}_{t}(1) and 𝐱←t​(2)subscript←𝐱𝑡2\overleftarrow{{\bf x}}_{t}(2) denote the X-axis and Y-axis, respectively. S≥0𝑆0S\geq 0 and S=0𝑆0S=0 only when the transport is a straight path.

We report the straightness in Table 4 and find the improvement of VSDM-10 over SGM-20 and SGM-30 is around 40%. We also tried VSDM-20 on both datasets and found a significant improvement over the baseline SGM methods. However, despite the consistent convergence in Figure 9, we found VSDM-20 still performs slightly worse than VSDM-10, which implies the potential to tune βmaxsubscript𝛽\beta_{\max} to further enhance the performance.

D.2.4 A Smaller Number of Function Evaluations

We also compare our VSDM-20 with SGM-20 based on a small number of function evaluations (NFE). We use probability flow to conduct the experiments and choose a uniform time grid for convenience. We find that both models cannot fully generate the desired data with NFE=6 in Figure 10 and VSDM appears to recover more details, especially on the top and bottom of the spiral. For the checkboard data, both models work nicely under the same setting and we cannot see a visual difference. With NFE=8 in Figure 11, we observe that our VSDM-20 works remarkably well on both datasets and is slightly superior to SGM-20 in generating the corner details.

D.3 Multivariate Probabilistic Forecasting

Data.

We use publicly available datasets. Exchange rate has 6071 8-dimensional measurements and a daily frequency. The goal is to predict the value over the next 30 days. Solar is an hourly 137-dimensional dataset with 7009 values. Electricity is also hourly, with 370 dimensions and 5833 measurements. For both, we predict the values over the next day.

Training.

We adopt the encoder-decoder architecture as described in the main text, and change the decoder to either our generative model or one of the competitors. The encoder is an LSTM with 2 layers and a hidden dimension size 64. We train the model for 200 epochs, where each epoch takes 50 model updates. In case of our model we also alternate between two training directions at a predefined rate. The neural network parameterizing the backward direction has the same hyperparameters as in (Rasul et al., 2021), that is, it has 8 layers, 8 channels, and a hidden dimension of 64. The DDPM baseline uses a standard setting for the linear beta-scheduler: βmin=0.0001subscript𝛽min0.0001\beta_{\text{min}}=0.0001, βmax=0.1subscript𝛽max0.1\beta_{\text{max}}=0.1 and 150 steps.
